text1: Several heavy thrusters that slowly recharge off a small auxiliary reactor, granting a quick boost of agility and speed.
text3: Grants a brief boost to speed and agility.

text1: Drone manufactories of the Resolute can instantly re-deploy all destroyed drones, plus field three additional drones, for a short time. Can exhaust supply with repeated power surges.
text3: Redeploy all drones, plus an additional drone per each bay, for a small flux and replacement rate cost.

text1:
A trans-atmospheric gunship frigate packed with late-Domain technologies and a high-specification reactor. Mount flexibility ensures that this frigate--though expensive to maintain and deploy--is never out of place in any fleet. It is unfortunately also among the most fragile of frigates due to a lack of "empty" space and limited redundancies.

Despite its description mentioning "trans-atmospheric", the Colubris must undergo a brief period of preparation to engage in atmospheric flight. This process requires most weapon emplacements be retracted to reduce air friction, leaving the ship with just two point defense mounts.  Still, it is generally favored by Star Federation diplomatic officials, serving as both the security of a warship and a symbol of pride conduct business from.

Taking advantage of the unstable nature of hyperspace, the core of the ship is uniquely capable of creating a microfracture around the entire ship. Though vulnerable while "charging", this quick FTL jump provides more distance than a traditional phasic "skip" and its high technological requirements.
text3: Jumps to nearby location, but lowers shield and becomes vulnerable for a brief time.

text1: A backup battery supercharges all engines and weapons for a short period of time. Increases ship speed and weapon refire rates 150%, and reduces weapon flux cost by 50%.
text3: Gain a sharply decaying boost of agility, speed, rate of fire, and reduction weapon flux cost.

text1: A backup battery supercharges all engines and weapons for a short period of time. Increases ship speed and weapon refire rates 150%, and reduces weapon flux cost by 50%.
text3: Gain a sharply decaying boost of agility, speed, rate of fire, and reduction weapon flux cost.

text1: Additional fuel injectors increase thrust and engine response times dramatically, but prevent any braking effects while active.
text3: Boosts engine performance for a short period, but prevents everything but forward movement.

text1:
The Super Buffalo is a Federation variant on the typical Load-n-Pray Buffalo freighter. Modern minimum defense specifications complement extra crew amenities like SonicShowers, automated point defense, and noise-isolated berthing slots. Other improvements come at a higher maintenance cost and do not grant the ship any significant benefits outside of the engine system. While boosters give the Super Buffalo a higher chance to escape hostile forces, it would be foolish to expect a flawless survival rate.

The Super Buffalo's business prospects are admittedly rather bleak, as the number of potential buyers capable of affording it is surprisingly small due to the tense factional politics of the Star Federation and the increasing competence of pirates. Corporate trading managers often opt for the standard Buffalo instead, as it offers higher marginal profits and when shadowed by for patrols in core-system lanes. Despite this, the ergonomics of the Super Buffalo means it has a greater chance of appearing in the protective formations of scavenger and privateer fleets.

A mysterious mix of Star Federation refinement and "low tech" technology, the Nisos clearly a Star Federation Osprey converted to provide ballistic fire support. Its forward firepower appears to exceed or match that of the heaviest cruisers in existence, nevermind the presence of numerous power conduits hooked up to feed-lines around the ship. Several locations on the vessel appear have missing components and abruptly-ending network lines, suggesting there was some kind of informational relay planned at each point.

What little couple be extracted from ship's data logs mentions a clandestine organization known as Section 23. In contradiction to the public knowledge of the Star Federation and its various internal factions, this organization doesn't seem to exist. From what you can gather, Section 23 was--or is--a breakaway group that has gone to great lengths to conceal its existence, with relevant constructional data suggesting that significant resources and materials were diverted to its cause during the chaos of the AI Wars. Clearly, there is much more to learn about Section 23 and its goals.

At least, for now, you feel it is likely an isolated discovery.

A ship-length, front-mounted "scrap" cannon that fires an expanding cloud of projectiles at extended ranges. While individually weak and therefore less effective against armor, the sum damage of projectiles can overwhelm shield generators.

The specially-designed projectiles of Scrapshot weapons collapse inwards on themselves on impact, fusing their cores in a millionth of a second. The resulting micro-fusion bursts cause equal damage across all types of defense and produce electromagnetic effects that potentially disrupt weaker components. The only drawback of the artillery variant is the considerably longer capacitor charge time, but range and damage are noticeably increased.

The Hirondelle is a omni-purpose trans-atmospheric shuttle with the ability to launch ground assaults, and represents a bold Federation reimagination of the popular Kite shuttle. While it boasts impressive offensive capabilities with its spaceborne weapon package, the small size of the vessel makes it ill-suited for space combat. Despite this drawback, fleet logisticians intoxicated by cost-effectiveness reports tend to embrace the Hirondelle, clearly having never set foot on one headed into the thick of battle.

Dubbed the "Dodo" by its spacer crew, the Hirondelle is indeed quite large and ungainly for a trans-atmospheric ship. This is largely due to the space required for its trooper complement, whose cramped and spartan living quarters can accommodate nearly a hundred (unhappy) marines and their suits. Most of them are situated in the midsection underbelly, located unnervingly close to the bombs bays meant to soften up prospective targets. It's no surprise the troopers call the ship the "Doodoo" instead, but with varying degrees of language severity.

A technologically advanced hull, the Emerillon defies its destroyer classification with superior maneuverability and firepower. Built around a one-of-a-kind rotary cannon, the ridiculous performance of its main weapon melts large and small targets alike. A perfect ship for ambitious Star Federation officers seeking glory, but also rare due to construction costs and tactical rigidity.

Conceptualized during the peak of Star Federation design capability, the surprising efficiency of its inner systems might suggest the design was assisted by an AI. Containing "power surge" systems reminiscent of the Rebellion, the Emerillon's disruptive emissions and high maintenance profile irritates quartermasters and fleet coordinators alike.

A powerful rotary gun designed to shred and destroy medium-to-light targets, the Repressor's flux costs are kept reasonable by the incredible amount of support equipment built into Emerillon. Few weapons in the sector can match its terrible assault, especially when its mothership engages its Redline ship system. It is estimated to cost about 400,000 centi-credits every twelve minutes of operation.

Amazingly, the entire Repressor complex is largely automated by Delta-class AI systems, right down to hyper-cooling arrays, recoil dampers, and fire control systems. Perhaps, in light of this autonomy, auxiliary systems such as life support and berthing are pushed to the side pontoons of the craft. Such isolation does leave plenty of space in the main hull for customization, even if it does result in less radiation protection for the crew.

An elusive "modified" version of the already rare base model, the Magnellion is faster and more dangerous than its ballsistic counterpart. Despite having roughly the same combat premise, it offers a radically different main armament in the form of a rotary plasma pulser. Doubled conduits and internal reconfiguration brings minor improvements to the engines and shields over its ballistic counterpart - no doubt a work of some ingenious underworld chiphacker.

Though the Emerillon's main weapon was always planned to be interchangeable, the effort never panned out. A large reason was Domain suppression campaigns putting pressure on the Star Federation, triggering a shift of budgets towards production instead of design. An extra reactor replaces the autofactory complex in the Magnellion, but the power is almost entirely consumed by the main gun. Much like its cousin, the true potential of this raider could possibly be found in the disengaging of its saftey interlocks.

A rapid-fire energy cannon with excellent generalist utility, but suffers accuracy loss during prolonged firing. Affectionately titled "Spinthrasher" by the underworld chiphackers in possession of the original blueprint.

The Spinthrasher utilizes a form of laser ignition system to superheat special reaction pellets. Uneven combustion on one side of the pellet creates a directional explosion that fires the fusion pellet out with significant velocity. The laser assembly itself is kept safe with powerful magnetic containment fields, and the weapon utilizes multiple supercooled barrels to manage the heat from residual plasma.
A largely inconspicuous variant of the Swarm Battery missile system which trades modularity for high-quality ammoforges and targeted burst capability.

The irony of an anti-pirate vessel falling into pirate hands made real, this flying disregard-for-safety was custom-crafted by its pirate crew for extreme speed and lethality. A well-to-do pirate boss haphazardly ordered secondary reactors behind bulkheads, simplified missile mounts, and ignored the immense cost of permanently overdriving the ship's entire system. But somehow, it worked.

A heavily armed and armored destroyer designed to pose a threat to cruisers, the Cormorant wields supercharged ballistic mounts and ungainly missile capacity for its tonnage. Upon expending its missiles, the lack of follow-through or initiation may leave it somewhat passive for a heavy destroyer.

Created to oppose rickety pirate gun-barges common in with wilder ages of the Persean Arm, this old model destroyer follows a practical and simplistic doctrine: Missiles are limited, but so are enemy reinforcements. The success of this philosophy has allowed the simple Cormorant to persevere in Federation doctrine throughout the many cycles.

The vaguely organic flow of the Stormwalker's hull gives no reasonable answer to the problems it poses: How does a vessel this large enter p-space without a proper phase-coil array? Even ignoring the impossible question, the craft never appears to dive as deep as normal phasecraft might. Sensors also reveal a phase density unnatural for the ship's real size, as well as temporal fluidity that eminates from strange crystalline arrays dispersed throughout in the hull. The vessel is otherwise standard for a Federation-pattern hull, except for an array of curious shock-pylons that disable nearby threats.

The crystals appear to be a kind of temporal resonance generators, a concept once thought exclusive to ultra-rare prototype Tri-Tachyon hulls. Being borne of two greatest Domain ultratechs, this "Stormwalker" would certainly condemned by Luddic sects across the sector as a fruit from Moloch's tree. After all, this vessel was surely reft from the minds of unfathomably intelligent AI cores, assuming such artefact were able to exist outside of the Domain's clutches.

Phase ships are rumored to be disturbing places for their crew and officers. This is also true of the Stormwalker, whose entire hull seems to produce unqiuely "aural" stress sounds when its phase filaments glow hot with flux. Such behavior is inconsistent with the limited research data available Domain pattern dimensional coils, but apparently not concerning than "normal" phase operation.

Thickly armored by Star Federation standards, the Shivan is highly reminiscent of "low tech" era ships. The Shivan features a micro-missile replicator to replenish smaller missiles from a large bank of feedstock. Perhaps one of the least unique "lost vessels" found in the far sectors, but perhaps that which is most familiar can also be the most useful.

Though the true story of this hull may be forever lost, evidence of the Federation's legacy remains on-board. Specifically, "warp" jump-drives once promised mid-range intergalactic traversal without the need for gates. Jump beacons connected Federation systems and provided convienient access to their overspecialized industrial bases, much to the ire of Domain planners. 

Unfortunately, with the Collapse, the light of the Jump Beacons was also snuffed out, and any jump-drive ships in transit were scattershot across the far stars Persean region. Much of them are purportedly like the Shivan's design, though a few other patterns have been discovered across the cycles. Octavian High Command has never fielded any kind of these "alien" vessels as of yet, but have ruthlessly siezed such examples from black market dealers.

A mysterious jellyfish-like frigate marked by a unique phase-displacement and oversized weapons package. Though the craft's single phase coil is arguably undersized, several phase-resonant filaments seem to bind the hull a curious area of positively-charged p-space. The rest of frigate largely conforms to mundane Federation standards, save for a curious pair of shock vanes providing point defense coverage.

Quite a cramped ship that presents itself like the inside of a creatures' ribcage, the Polyp has a disturbing lack of access points for critical life support systems. While being unable to directly interact with essential equipemnt like air cyclers suggests an impossible level of design oversight, a compliment of slug-like repair drones quickly attends to minor ship damage by excreting a rapidly-hardening smart repair gel.
Fires a large number of flak canisters with variable-timed proximity fuses all around the ship. More charges, but a lower reloading rate.
text3: Fires a large number of flak canisters with variable-timed proximity fuses all around the ship. Each canister deals 200 High Explosive damage in an area and is targeted to avoid friendly fire. The light version is slower to cycle and replenish charges.

text1: Gradually doubles weapon fire rate and engine power. System termination or ship overload produces an explosion of energy projectiles and a short overload, each scaling up depending on the ship's flux level.
text3: Slowly doubles weapon fire rate and engine power, followed by an explosion of energy and short overload. Both scale higher depending on the ship's flux level.

text1: The immense flux core of the Rebellion is uniquely suited to dumping overload energy into space. The wavefront is incredibly destructive at close range and is laden with enough ionic energy to disrupt an entire fleet. While friendly ships can polarize themselves for immunity, any nearby enemies or neutral entities will be affected.

A Rebellion given a hostile coat of orange paint and glimmering neon-teal lines, this battleship is a modification of the Rebellion used by seditious Federation worlds siding with the Hegemony during the Second AI war. Opponents are quick to see how the powerful energy weapon grid has been exchanged for numerous ammunition bunkers and ammo-feed lines. This brutal vessel is much more potent at standoff ranges than the mainline version, though at a marginal cost to its shield and flux systems. 

Though the war ended with the signing of the treaty, and these rebellious worlds collapsed without support, the havoc these distinctive vessels caused undoubtably left Scaria the only unruined Federation world. Like most traitor assets, these models were captured, evaluated, and then disposed of - usually discarded by dropping them into the crushing depths of a gas giant.

Rumors say there were proposed plans to make the Rebellion an even larger vessel. Proposedly split into three separate hulls, each with different power grids, this class of megaship would have likely demanded the attention of entire fleets. Unsurprisingly, the size of such a hull is assumed to be impossible with current technologies. And given the remarkable upkeep of existing Rebellion-class ships, it would likely be an impractical logistical burden, nevermind a strategically-unwieldy method of force projection.
Increases fighter wing speed by 30% and modestly increases the fire-rate and flux efficiency of non-missile weapons on the mothership. Generates a moderate amount of flux.

A fairly unimpressive anti-armor beam at a glance, the Hull Beam produces powerful "particle spall" explosions that ruin exposed hull.

Theoretical particle physicists imagine the effects of these "hull beams" originate from a quantum pairing effect between virtual particles in our spacetime and those of the infamous P-space dimension. The rapid oscillation of each other's phases between dimensions destabilizes, managing to produce twice the destructive effect when the particle stream is interrupted by a physical object. The charged nature of intruding particles means it is attracted to physical components, producing little hyperspace distortions that violently ionize pockets of gas located near energy sources.

Though not an outstanding weapon if solely judged by the hard-numbers, the Hull Beam II's secondary cavitation and explosive effects can blow out the bulkheads of any exposed target.

Theoretical particle physicists imagine the effects of these "hull beams" originate from a quantum pairing effect between virtual particles in our spacetime and those of the infamous P-space dimension. The rapid oscillation of each other's phases between dimensions destabilizes, managing to produce twice the destructive effect when the particle stream is interrupted by a physical object. The charged nature of intruding particles means it is attracted to physical components, producing little hyperspace distortions that violently ionize pockets of gas located near energy sources.

The long accelerator rail and upscaled capacitors of the Pike allow it to pressure targets from afar. Somewhat underpowered versus shields and armor, but ideal for support vessels and light craft.

Essentially the same "caliber" as the Microbeam, the Pike's introduction came relatively quickly as Federation weapon design institutions struggled with new lens refinement and energy pump mechanisms. Though the ungainly particle chute greatly accelerated the stream, the effect of the beam impact remained oddly unchanged. While the silhouette is amusing at first glance, the maintenance process for re-aligning a distorted guidance pylon is no joke.

A snub-nosed exotic particle beam with good range and punch. Nearly useless versus shields, but produces a destructive spalling effect on bare hull. 

Powered by a mysterious crystal substrate, the base-emitter of the Microbeam is grown from a fragment of crystal sample distributed across several forge facilities. Each beam shard is grown in conditions that could only be described as a "stellar nursery", an extremely hot but somewhat low-pressure atomic soup pulsed by radiation. Most crystals come out malformed, but a few can be extracted, milled down, and eventually fitted to the frame of a weapon.

A simple discharge can be achieved by cryogenically cooling a electrically charged crystal until it begins to violently dump its excess energy. The larger the core is, the longer it takes to discharge - but all produce a stream of exotic particles that violently self-obliterate anything not protected by a specifically calibrated magnetic field. Such short-lived and enigmatic things were seemingly difficult to study even before the Collapse, nevermind in the state of current Sector conditions.

An advanced launcher that fires devastating flux-charged torpedoes. Through poorly understoond means, the Red Drum sacrifices raw damage to create an enormous secondary explosion on the impacted target. The size of its warhead unfortunately leaves little room for maneuvering thrusters or fuel.

A triple battery of pressurized launch tubes for the Dace MRM. The charged warhead of this direct-fire missile deals extra damage to armor and hull with curious arc effects, but leaves little room for maneuvering thrusters or fuel.

A pair of pressurized launch tubes for the direct-fire Mooneye MRM, complete with a generous internal magazine. Named after an aquatic creature on old earth, the blue flash of the Mooneye's particle jet impactor is highly effective at destabalizing shields and irradiating exposed hull. The size of its warhead unfortunately leaves little room for maneuvering thrusters or fuel.

A complex of pressurized launch tubes for a larger variant of the Mooneye MRM, using a small auto-assembler to greatly increase missile storage count. Named after an aquatic creature on old earth, the blue flash of the Mooneye's particle jet impactor is highly effective at destabalizing shields and irradiating exposed hull. The size of its warhead unfortunately leaves little room for maneuvering thrusters or fuel.
Increases missile projectile speed and missile weapon reload rate. Also gives a smaller performance boost to engine power and ballistic weapon fire rate.
text3: Increases missile projectile speed and missile weapon reload rate. Also slightly boosts engine power and ballistc weapon fire rate.

text1: A small pressure-tube launcher for the direct-fire Mooneye MRM, whose mostly inert design allows for a large magazine. Named after an aquatic creature on old earth, the flash of the Mooneye's particle jet impactor is highly effective at destabalizing shields and irradiating exposed bulkheads. The size of its warhead unfortunately leaves little room for maneuvering thrusters or fuel.

A miniature pressure-launch tube for the Dace, with a large internal magazine thanks to the smaller warhead. The exotic particle bomblet in the missile creates a secondary explosion on the target hull, but leaves little room for maneuvering thrusters or fuel.

A heavily-armored and clumsy torpedo tipped with a baryonic particle core. When it hits hull or shields, the collapsing energy circuit surges energy to a point on the target. While shields can only mitigate the effect, smaller craft can normally evade the missile outright.
Flameout or damage up to half of the target ship's engines. Single engine ships will flameout, and engineless targets receive a heavy burst of EMP.
text3: Disable up to half of the target ship's engines. Single engine ships will flameout, and engineless targets receive a heavy burst of EMP.

text1:
A vessel designed to perpetuate the Legion's long standing (and mostly well censored) service to the countless anti-Domain rebellions of old, the Star Federation Legion is a highly modernized ship compared to its predecessors. With the amount of design concessions required facilitate energy weapons and additional subsystems, it is unsurprising to learn it is more or less an entirely new ship built around the skeletal superstructure of a normal Legion. It is certainly a variant that might cause a spacer to glance over their scans twice. Perhaps three or four times if they serve under the Phoenix crest of the Hegemony.

While Hegemony leadership might argue whether or not the normal Legion's brutish burns conflict with its ability to provide long-range fire support, the Federation legion suffers a different problem. An energy centric-ship such as this would undoubtedly benefit from close range maneuvers, but cost and engineering concessions reduce the already "thin" armor of the Legion firmly into midline territory. The flux system also leaves much to be desired, given that most of the craft's volume is relegated to special technologies like missile-microforges and secondary shield infrastructure.

This relatively expensive and higher-maintenance pattern was likely used by new and affluent rebel worlds who, while far from Star Federation facilities, could use this Legion retrofit to put the Federation's technological innovations to work. How such a craft ended up in one of the hearts of the Star Federation's industrial bases is a mystery, but not an especially pressing one.
